column45: Randy Johnson's no-hitter against the Braves was the 17th perfect game in MLB history and, at 40, he became the oldest pitcher ever to throw a perfect game.

column25: Randy Milligan (BAL) vs. Les Lancaster (DET) on 4/17/1992 (7th inning)
column26: Butch Davis (TEX) vs. Arthur Rhodes (BAL) on 8/22/1993 (3rd inning)
column45: Hideo Nomo's April 4th no-hitter came on the second day of the season and is the earliest in the year for any no-hitter thrown in an active park.

column20: Hugh Bradley (BOS) vs. Lefty Russell (PHA) on 4/26/1912 (7th inning)
column25: Rabbit Maranville (BSN) vs. Hippo Vaughn (CHN) on 9/26/1914 (4th inning)
column26: Sam Crawford (DET) vs. Buck O'Brien (BOS) on 5/10/1912 (9th inning)
column45: In the first regular season game at Fenway Park Red Sox players lost potential triples and home runs thanks to an overflow crowd that was roped off in the outfield.  Hits into the crowd were ruled doubles.; The first homer at Fenway Park was the last of Hugh Bradley's career; The first grand slam at Fenway Park was hit by Boston Braves shortstop Rabbit Maranville and was the last of his career.;  It was the first time that a park's regular home team didn't account for a first (both grand slam and no-hitter); Red Sox second baseman Steve Yerkes had five hits, the most ever for a park's first game.

column9: Weeghman Park; Cubs Park; Whales Park; North Side Ball Park
column10: Chicago Whales vs. Kansas City Packers: 4/23/1914
column20: Art Wilson (CHF) vs. Chief Johnson (KCF) on 4/23/1914 (2nd inning)
column25: Rollie Zeider (CHF) vs. Harry Moran (BUF) on 5/6/1914 (4th inning)
column26: Max Flack (CHF) vs. Gene Packard (KCF) on 7/11/1915 (3rd inning)
column45: Kansas City Packers pitcher Chief Johnson was served with legal papers in the second inning, enjoining him from pitching for Kansas City for the rest of the opener; John Potts, who recorded the first hit at then-Weeghman Park, had only 27 career hits, the fewest for a player who recorded the first hit at an active park; Chicago Whales catcher Art Wilson hit the first two home runs at the park in his first two at-bats; The first no-hitter thrown at Wrigley Field was a double no-hitter for nine innings between Cincinnati's Fred Toney and Chicago's Hippo Vaughn before the Reds recorded the first hit in the 10th inning; The first grand slam was hit by Rollie Zeider, who hit only five home runs in his nine-year career, and was the only homer he hit over the fence on the fly (the other four were either inside-the-park homers or bounced, which counted as homers at the time).

column20: Cecil Fielder (DET) vs. Jack McDowell (CHA) on 4/18/1991 (3rd innng)
column25: Kevin Romine (BOS) vs. Alex Fernandez (CHA) on 5/5/1991 (2nd inning)
column26: Mark Newfield (SEA) vs. Brian Keyser (CHA) on 6/21/1995 (5th inning)
column44: Francisco Liriano (MIN) vs. White Sox on 5/3/2011
column45: The Tigers' 16 runs are the most in a park's first game (minimum 300 games) and the 16-run margin of victory is the largest; Chicago White Sox pitcher Mark Buerhle threw the first two no-hitters at U.S. Cellular Field, making him the only pitcher to toss the first two no-hitters at an active park; All three no-hitters at U.S. Cellular Field were thrown by southpaws; Tigers teammates Tony Phillips and Alan Trammell had four hits each in the first game at U.S. Cellular Field, becoming the only teammates with four hits in a park's first game; Kevin Romine, who hit the first grand slam at U.S. Cellular Field, hit only five home runs in his career and the grand slam was his last.  He also holds the distinction of having the fewest career home runs among those who hit a park's first grand slam (tied with Rollie Zeider).

column20: Reggie Sanders (PIT) vs. Jimmy Haynes (CIN) on 3/31/2003 (2nd inning)
column25: Carlos Delgado (TOR) vs. John Reidling (CIN) on 6/6/2003 (2nd inning)
column26: Eric Young (MIL) vs. Jeff Austin (CIN) on 5/11/2003 (6th inning)
column45: Great American Ballpark is one of four parks to open in March; One of three parks where the first grand slam came in an interleague game (Chase Field: 1998 and Safeco Field:1999); Homer Bailey's no-hitter was his second in 19 starts. His first also had the distinction of being the first no-hitter thrown at Pittsburgh's PNC Park and he became the second pitcher to throw the first no-hitter at multiple parks (Hideo Nomo: 1996, 2001).

column20: Eric Anthony (SEA) vs. Dennis Martinez (CLE) on 4/4/1994 (3rd inning)
column25: Paul Sorrento (CLE) vs. Doug Linton (KCA) on 5/9/1995 (1st inning)
column26: David Bell (CLE) vs. Randy Johnson (SEA) on 4/15/1998 (1st inning)
column45: David Bell hit the first inside-the-park home run at then-Jacobs Field in the bottom of the first inning against Seattle's Randy Johnson.  Two innings later Johnson threw two pitches at Kenny Lofton's head and touched off a bench-clearing brawl, after which Johnson, Lofton, and Indians catcher Sandy Alomar Jr. were ejected from the game.; The first no-hitter was thrown 17 years after the park opened, the longest gap among active parks in which a no-hitter has been thrown.  Interestingly, Cleveland's League Park boasts the longest gap---21 years---among inactive parks in which a no-hitter was thrown.  Washington's Griffith Stadium went 20 years before the first no-hitter was thrown and Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium went 19 years.

column20: Rico Brogna (NYN) vs. Bill Swift (COL) on 4/26/1995 (4th inning)
column25: Todd Hundley (NYN) vs. Bill Swift (COL) on 4/26/1995 (6th inning)
column26: Ellis Burks (COL) vs. Mike Williams (PHI) on 6/14/1996 (1st inning)
column45: Coors Field is the first active park to feature a grand slam in its first game (Yankee Stadium II: 4/16/2009), and the second (Jarry Park: 4/14/1969) among all parks (minimum 300 games); Hideo Nomo has thrown the only no-hitter at Coors Field (through 2015) and when he tossed a no-hitter at Oriole Park at Camden Yards in 2001, he became the first pitcher to throw the first no-hitters at two different active parks.  His no-hitter at Coors Field is the only one with an attendance of at least 50,000 (among active parks); The 14-inning game between the Rockies and Mets was the longest (by innings) of any first game in a park (minimum 300 games).; Three umpires---Mike Riggins, Joe Padilla, and Dick Jackson---made their MLB debuts in the first game at Coors Field.

column25: Trot Nixon (BOS) vs. Jim Poole (DET) on 4/19/2000 (6th inning)
column26: Juan Gonzalez (DET) vs. Kenny Rogers (TEX) on 9/2/2000 (1st inning)
column45: Juan Gonzalez is the only player to hit the first homer and first inside-the-park homer in an active park.

column20: Scott Rolen (PHI) vs. Octavio Dotel (HOU) on 4/7/2000 (7th inning)
column25: Thomas Howard (SLN) vs. Chris Holt (HOU) on 4/11/2000 (7th inning)
column26: Adam Everett (HOU) vs. Pedro Feliciano (NYN) on 8/6/2003 (5th inning)
column45: Thomas Howard's grand slam came as a pinch-hitter, making him the first pinch-hitter to hit the first grand slam in an active park's first game.

column26: Vic Harris (TEX) vs. Bruce Dal Canton (KCA) on 6/24/1973 (9th inning)
column44: Bret Saberhagen (KCA) vs. White Sox on 8/26/1991
column45: Bruce Dal Canton is the only pitcher to allow the first grand slam and inside-the-park homer in a park.

column20: Wally Post (CIN) vs. Johnny Podres (LAN) on 4/10/1962 (7th inning)
column25: Brooks Robinson (BAL) vs. Ken McBride (LAA) on 5/6/1962 (3rd inning)
column26: Larry Burright (LAN) vs. Dave Hillman (NYN) on 5/25/1962 (6th inning)
column45: Hall of Fame umpire Doug Harvey and five-time All-Star Cookie Rojas both made their MLB debuts in Dodger Stadium's first game; Los Angeles Angels pitcher Bo Belinski threw the first no-hitter at Dodger Stadium on May 5, 1962 against the Baltimore Orioles.  The next day Orioles third baseman Brooks Robinson hit the first grand slam at Dodger Stadium in a game against the Angels, who called Dodger Stadium home from 1962-1965.

column20: J.D. Martinez (HOU) vs. Edward Mujica (MIA) on 4/13/2012 (8th inning)
column25: Giancarlo Stanton (MIA) vs. Manny Acosta (NYN) on 5/13/2012 (9th inning)
column26: Dee Gordon (MIA) vs. Ryan Vogelsong (SFN) on 6/30/2015 (2nd inning)
column45: Marlins Park is the only active park where a pitcher was the first strikeout victim; The first grand slam at Marlins Park, hit by Giancarlo Stanton, was a walk-off hit that gave the Marlins an 8-4 win over the New York Mets; Henderson Alvarez's no-hitter came in the final game of the regular season and is the only one ever to end on a wild pitch. It's also one of four parks where the first no-hitter came in an interleague game.

column20: Michael Tucker (CIN) vs. Jeff D'Amico (MIL) on 4/6/2001 (4th inning)
column25: Jose Hernandez (MIL) vs. Nelson Cruz (HOU) on 4/12/2001 (5th inning)
column26: Fernando Vina (SLN) vs. Ben Sheets (MIL) on 10/2/2001 (5th inning)
column45: Michael Tucker is the only player to drive in the first run in the first game at two parks (minimum 300 games); Michael Tucker is the only player to hit the first home run in the first game in two active parks, and is the second player (Buck Freeman: 1901, 1903) to hit the first homers in the first game in two parks (minimum 300 games); Miller Park is the only ballpark that hosted a no-hitter as a neutral site when the Houston Astros were displaced from Houston due to Hurricane Ike; Fernando Vina became the first player to hit the first inside-the-park home runs in two parks (minimum 300 games).

column20: Jason Kubel (MIN) vs. Scott Atchison (BOS) on 4/12/2012 (7th inning)
column25: Matt Joyce (TBA) vs. Matt Guerrier (MIN) on 7/3/2010 (8th innng)
column26: Curtis Granderson (NYA) vs. Jose Mijares (MIN) on 8/21/2011 (7th inning)
column45: Matt Joyce's grand slam came as a pinch-hitter, making him the second pinch-hitter to hit the first grand slam in an active park's first game (Thomas Howard at Minute Maid Park: 4/11/2000).

column20: Jody Gerut (SDN) vs. Mike Pelfrey (NYN) on 4/13/2009 (1st inning)
column25: Omir Santos (NYN) vs. Anibal Sanchez (FLA) on 4/27/2009 (1st inning)
column26: Angel Pagan (NYN) vs. Pedro Martinez (PHI) on 8/23/2009 (1st inning)
column45: San Diego Padres center fielder Jody Gerut led off the first game at Citi Field with a home run, making it the only park to open with a homer (minimum 300 games); Johan Santana's no-hitter was the first ever thrown by a Mets pitcher and occurred in the team's 51st season and 8,020th game, which was the longest drought any franchise had endured before recording its first no-hitter.  It took only three more years before the second no-hitter was thrown and the third was thrown less than four months later.

column20: Jorge Posada (NYA) vs. Cliff Lee (CLE) on 4/16/2009 (5th inning)
column25: Grady Sizemore (CLE) vs. Damaso Marte (NYA) on 4/16/2009 (7th inning)
column26: Brett Gardner (NYA) vs. Jesse Crain (MIN) on 5/15/2009 (7th inning)
column45: Yankee Stadium II is the second active park to feature a grand slam in its first game (Coors Field: 4/26/1995), and the third (Jarry Park: 4/14/1969) among all parks (minimum 300 games).

column9: Network Associates Coliseum; McAfee Coliseum; UMAX Coliseum; Overstock.com Coliseum
column20: Boog Powell (BAL) vs. Lew Krausse (OAK) on 4/17/1968 (2nd inning)
column25: Sal Bando (OAK) vs. George Brunet (CAL) on 4/16/1969 (5th inning)
column26: Reggie Jackson (OAK) vs. Jim McGlothlin (CAL) on 6/2/1968 (4th inning)
column45: Catfish Hunter threw the first no-hitter at Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum in the 11th game ever played there, marking the shortest amount of time between a park's first game and its first no-hitter; Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum has hosted three no-hitters in which more than one pitcher contributed, including two in which four pitchers contributed.  Turner Field in Atlanta is the only other active park that has hosted a no-hitter in which four pitchers contributed, and only Turner Field, Fenway Park, and Angel Stadium of Anaheim have hosted other no-hitters in which multiple pitchers contributed.

column20: Bobby Abreu (PHI) vs. Paul Wilson (CIN) on 4/12/2004 (1st inning)
column25: Andruw Jones (ATL) vs. Kevin Millwood (PHI) on 5/27/2004 (4th inning)
column26: Jimmy Rollins (PHI) vs. Dennys Reyes (KCA) on 6/20/2004 (2nd inning)
column45: When Randy Wolf started the first game at Citizens Bank Park on 4/12/2004 he became the first pitcher to start the first game at two active parks (Minute Maid Park: 4/7/2000 ); When Ken Griffey Jr. struck out in the first innng at Citizens Bank Park's first game he became the first strikeout victim in the first game at two different parks; The first no-hitter thrown at Citizens Bank Park, by Roy Halladay in Game One of the NLDS , was only the second no-hitter thrown in the postseason (Don Larsen: Perfect game in Game Five of the 1956 World Series).

column20: Vinny Castilla (COL) vs. Andy Benes (ARI) on 3/31/1998 (6th inning)
column25: Cecil Fielder (ANA) vs. Willie Blair (ARI) on 6/9/1998 (3rd inning)
column26: Wendell McGee (DET) vs. Curth Schilling (ARI) on 6/14/2002 (3rd inning)
column45: When Chase Field opened on March 31, 1998 it became the second park to open in March (Tropicana Field opened a few hours earlier on 3/31/1998).  Great American Ballpark in Cincinnati opened on 3/31/2003, making it the third park to open in March, then Nationals Park topped all three when it opened on March 30, 2008.

column20: Sean Casey (CIN) vs. Todd Ritchie (PIT) on 4/9/2001 (1st inning)
column25: Sammy Sosa (CHN) vs. Jose Silva (PIT) on 4/20/2001 (9th inning)
column26: Jack Wilson (PIT) vs. Brooks Kieschnick (MIL) on 7/2/2004 (6th inning)
column45: When Barry Larkin led off in the first game at PNC Park he became the first player to lead off in the first game at two different active parks, having also led off in the first game at Milwaukee's Miller Park three days before; Barry Larkin was also the first batter to open an active park with a strikeout; When Sean Casey recorded the first hit at PNC Park he became the only player to earn the first hit at two active parks.

column20: Marquis Grissom (SFN) vs. Pablo Osuna (SDN) on 4/8/2004 (10th inning)

column26: Jimmy Rollins (PHI) vs. Adam Eaton (SDN) on 8/4/2004 (4th inning)
column45: Marquis Grissom is the only player to hit the first homer at an active park in extra innings and is only the second one to do it (Bill Bruton: 4/14/1953) in parks that hosted at least 300 games.; Jimmy Rollins is the second player  to hit the first inside-the-park home run in two active parks (Fernando Vina); Tim Lincecum was part of two no-hitters in 11 days, including the first one thrown at Great American Ballpark in Cincinnati.

column20: Russ Davis (SEA) vs. Woody Williams (SDN) on 7/17/1999 (5th inning)
column25: Raul Ibanez (SEA) vs. Carlos Reyes (SDN) on 7/17/1999 (7th inning)
column26: Adrian Beltre (SEA) vs. Mike Timlin (BOS) on 7/23/2006 (8th inning)
column45: When Safeco Field hosted its first game on 7/15/1999 it was the latest an active park had ever opened, and fourth latest (Braves Field: 8/18/1915, Cleveland Stadium: 7/31/1932, Three Rivers Stadium: 7/16/1970) among all parks that hosted at least 300 games.

column20: Kevin Elster (LAN) vs. Kirk Rueter (SFN) on 4/11/2000 (3rd inning)
column25: Bobby Estalella (SFN) vs.  Glendon Rusch (NYN) on 5/2/2000 (4th inning)
column26: Fernando Vina (SLN) vs. Russ Ortiz (SFN) on 5/9/2000 (2nd inning)
column45: Kevin Elster is the only player to hit the first home run in a park in a game in which he hit three (minimum 300 games).  It was the only three-homer game of his career.; Fernando Vina is the first player to hit the first inside-the-park home runs in two active parks.

column45: When Mark Mulder homered in the 7th inning in the first game at Busch Stadium III he became the only pitcher to homer in an active park's first game.

column20: Luis Gonzalez (DET) vs. Dan Carlson (TBA) on 3/31/1998 (5th inning)
column25: Johnny Damon (KCA) vs. Dennis Springer (TBA) on 5/14/1998 (2nd inning)
column26: Dave Martinez (TBA) vs. Hideki Irabu (NYA) on 7/10/1998 (4th inning)
column27: Edwin Jackson (ARI) vs. Devil Rays on 6/25/2010
column45: Tropicana Field was the first park to open in March, beating Arizona's Chase Field by a few hours.  At the time it was the earliest a new park had opened, but was eclipsed by Washington's Nationals Park when it hosted its first game on 3/30/2008.; Only nine games separated the first no-hitter thrown at Tropicana Field from the most recent, the smallest gap between no-hitters among active parks.

column25: Terry Steinbach (OAK) vs. Duane Ward (TOR) on 7/16/1989 (7th inning)

column27: Dave Stewart (OAK) vs. Blue Jays on 6/29/1990
column44: Justin Verlander (DET) vs. Blue Jays on 5/7/2011

column25: Felipe Lopez (WAS) vs. Aaron Heilman (NYN) on 4/24/2008 (6th inning)
column26: Angel Pagan (NYN) vs. Livan Hernandez (WAS) on 5/19/2010 (4th innng)
column45: When Nationals Park opened on 3/30/2008 it was the earliest date for a park's first game; Kelly Johnson was only the second player to open an active park with a strikeout (Barry Larkin); Angel Pagan is the third player to hit the first inside-the-park home run in two active parks (Fernando Vina, Jimmy Rollins); Jordan Zimmerman's no-hitter came on the last day of the regular season.
